lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can correctly use “There is” / “There are” and prepositions (next to, in front of, behind) to describe locations.
supportStrategies: (Grammar) Draw simple diagrams: “sofa next to table,” “lamp behind chair.” Ask: “Where is the ___?” Students answer using “There is/are” and prepositions.
stretchStrategies: Draw a simple "house map" on the board. One student closes their eyes. Their partner gives instructions using prepositions:
“Go behind the sofa. Turn right. What’s next to the cupboard?”
This builds listening, direction-following, and preposition accuracy.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can read and say words with different spelling patterns clearly and confidently.
supportStrategies: (Phonics) Display 4–6 words with different patterns. Students read and sort by shared spellings or underline matching sounds (e.g., ir, oo, ar).
stretchStrategies: Draw a simple "house map" on the board. One student closes their eyes. Their partner gives instructions using prepositions:
“Go behind the sofa. Turn right. What’s next to the cupboard?”
This builds listening, direction-following, and preposition accuracy.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can answer Yes/No questions about the location of items using complete sentences.
supportStrategies: (Writing) Ask: “Is there a bed in the garage?” Students write “Yes, there is.” or “No, there isn’t.” Then write their own question and answer.
stretchStrategies: Draw a simple "house map" on the board. One student closes their eyes. Their partner gives instructions using prepositions:
“Go behind the sofa. Turn right. What’s next to the cupboard?”
This builds listening, direction-following, and preposition accuracy.

items: Hai con chó >> two dog [two dogs]. Not only the form, but the pronunciation is tough here, as it changes depending on the final sound of the noun [s,z,iz]

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Often confused – Kindergarteners will tend to prefer 'it is' for everything, even though the Vietnamese is very different for the two structures

languageTransferAnalysis.section: 4. Plural forms of it is and there is:
items: Plural forms of these structures do not exist in Vietnamese. It's difficult for kids to remember to produce them, particularly because the plural element comes before the noun phrase. There are two houses
